Page | 1 1. Introduction  
This handbook briefly describes the Post Graduate Diploma in Management (PGDM) 
and the rules associated with the programme. It also lays out the details regarding 
personal and academic behaviour  as expected from a student of this programme. 
AIDTM believes in an environment based on trust, integrity, honesty, and impartiality. 
The students are expected to conduct themselves in a manner that would enhance the 
image and esteem of the Institute.  
2. Adani Group

Adani Group is one of India‚Äôs largest integrated infrastructure conglomerates with 
interests in Resources (coal mining and trading), Logistics (ports, logistics, shipping, and 
rail), Energy (renewable and thermal power generation, transmission, and distrib ution), 
and Agro (commodities, edible oil, food products, cold storage, and grain silos), Real 
Estate, Public Transport Infrastructure, Consumer Finance , and Defense.  
Adani group owes its success and leadership position to its core ph

ilosophy of ‚ÄòNation 
Building‚Äô and ‚ÄòGrowth with Goodness‚Äô ‚Äì a guiding principle for sustainable growth. The 
Group is committed to protecting the environment and improving communities through  
its CSR program based on the principles of sustainability, diversity, and shared values. 
Adani has been the vanguard of transposing the conduct of education by creating an 
infrastructure management institute, an engineering institute, and a Medical Colleg e. 
3. Adani Institute of Digital Technology Man

agement (AIDTM)  
At Adani Institute of Digital Technology Management (AIDTM), we are driven by 
stimulation and assurance. The need to bridge the gap between pioneering ideas and 
futuristic disruptive technology -driven innovation requires great learning. At Adani 
Institute of Digital Technology Management (AIDTM), this need is taken care of by the 
state -of-the-art campus, very learned faculties, and most importantly, Summer 
Internships, Capstone projects, and enviable placements at the be

st organizations.  
AIDTM was established in the year 2020, with the core adherence of creating 
continuously employable professionals in the field of Big Data Analytics  and Artificial 
Intelligence & Data Science . For non -tech background students too, they learn 
unknown correlations, market trends, and customer preferences that help make better 
decisions and prevent fraudulent activities in organizations.  
AIDTM is inspired and guided by esteemed leaders, who are known for their vision,
achievements, and charisma.

Page | 2  
Vision  
To emerge as an international center of excellence in the field of data science and 
digital technology. To create best talent helping to shape future India . 
Mission  
To develop/ create an international Institute to ensure that data science and digital 
technology is for everyone . 
4. PDGM Programme  
4.1 PGDM ( Big Data Analytics ) 
PGDM ( Big Data Analytics ) is an AICTE -approved two -year full -time specialized 
programme  for any graduates who are passionate abou

t shaping a career in Big Data 
Analytics . In the first year, students complete core courses that provide a thorough, and 
integrated foundation in management & big data analytics  essentials and a summer 
internship of 4 months while in the second year, they get exposure and hands -on 
experience on recent technologies related to big data analytics  and some elective 
courses of management domains. At the same time, students also get exposure to 
independent projects, semin ars, and finally, e

nd with a capstone project. The idea 
behind the capstone project is to leave an impact on the recruiters on the program‚Äôs 
delivery and to create confidence and empower students to face ‚Äúreal world‚Äù 
challenges.  
4.2 PGDM ( Artific ial Intelligence & Data Science ) 
PGDM (AI & DS) is an AICTE -approved two -year full -time specialized program for any 
graduates who are passionate about shaping various career paths like Data Scientist, 
AI Engineer, Business Analyst, and Machine Learning Engine

er. In the first year, 
student s complete core courses that provide a strong foundation in AI Data Science, 
Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Predictive Analytics, and Summer Internship while in 
the second year, they get exposure and hands -on experience on recent technologies 
Gen-AI, RPA , NLP, Data Engineering and Modelling related courses of technology and 
management domains. At the same time, students also get exposure to independent 
projects, seminars, and finally, end with a capstone

project of a 5 -month duration. The 
idea behind the capstone project is to leave an impact on the recruiters on the programs 
delivery and to create confidence and empower students to face real world challenges.

Page | 3 4.3 Programme Structure  
The structure of the PGDM primarily aims at providing individuals with ample 
opportunities to learn time -tested management principles as well as current best 
practices in the field of Big Data Analytics  and Artificial Intelligence & Data Science . It 
also provides exposure to evolving next -generation practices through active interaction 
with industry continuously. The structure of the programme is blended with core and 
elective courses spread over s

ix terms in two years. The first year of the PGDM  has core 
courses, whereas the focus of the second year is on elective courses from across 
different functional areas. In the final trimester, students undertake a Capstone Project, 
which helps students create confidence and empower students to face ‚Äúreal world‚Äù 
challenges.  
The academic year 2025 -27 begins in August 2025 (as per AICTE notification) and ends 
in May 202 7. The students are also required to complete an internship at the end

of the 
first year. If a student does not complete the minimum requirements for the award of a 
degree at the end of the programme, s/he can take two more years  (i.e., a maximum of 
2+2=4 years in total), to complete the programme, subject to fulfilment  of conditions 
stated later in this handbook. The PGDM programme offers core courses and elective 
courses. All core cours es are compulsory, and it is mandatory to pass these courses to 
be eligible for a degree. The list of 1st year courses o

ffered to the students of PGDM 
(2025 -27) is included in Annexur e I A & B (for PGDM BDA  and AI & DS ). 
5. Summer Internship Program  
To ensure  the overall development of necessary skills among the students and prepare 
them for real-life assignments, the students must undergo four months of a summer  
internship progra m. 
Internship is an important and integral part of the PGDM curriculum.  The placement 
cell will manage the process of getting Internship assignments for the students.  
6

. Pedagogy  
AIDTM strongly believes in equipping budding techno managers with the latest 
pedagogical tools which are largely student -driven. To accomplish this, the Institute 
follows a sensible blend of Classroom Teaching, Lectures, Use Case Discussion & 
Analysis, Pre sentations, Group Exercises, Simulations, Role Plays, Project Work, 
Industrial Visits, SIP and Capstone Projects , independent self -learning and learning 
beyond the classroom, etc. as pedagogy. Active participation in the l
earning process

Page | 4 facilitates budding managers to acquire knowledge, attitude, skills, and a mindset to 
handle varied and complex business problems successfully.  
7. Projects  
7.1 Group Projects ‚Äì A Chance for Growing Together  
Working with talented and accomplished peers provides a unique opportunity for 
accelerated professional and personal growth. Group projects are a major component 
of most courses, and help students develop and refine their skills in working with 
diverse gro ups. The grou

ps are formed from pools of varied disciplines, backgrounds, 
corporate experience, and career orientations to leverage the enormous diversity in 
perspectives.  
7.2 Capstone Project  
In the sixth trimester, students will undergo a Capstone Project. The Capstone Project 
places students in the driving seat to solve real -world business problems. Students will 
learn to face challenging and integrative problems of the real business world that 
require a techno -managerial perspective and are gl

obal.  
8. Student Feedback  
The students will be requested to provide their feedback twice in a term about the 
courses they have attended.  The Program Office will circulate a Feedback 
Questionnaire to each student, which s/he is expected to complete and submit to the 
concerned official within the given session. When taken online, the students are 
allowed to fill in the feedback within a certa in pre -stipulated time interval on the 
corresponding portal. This feedback helps in further imp

roving the quality of the 
courses that are deliver ed to the students.  
9. Examinations  
1) Occupy the seat allotted to you in the seating chart. Every Student should be 
seated in the exam hall 10 minutes before the scheduled commencement of the 
paper. Entry into the examination hall after the commencement of the paper will 
be solely at the discretion of the examination coordinator, but in no case will the 
student be allowed to enter after the first half an hour of the exam.  
2) Each stu

dent must always wear his/her identity card and produce whenever 
asked. A student who is not displaying an identity card may not be allowed to 
take the examination.

Page | 5 3) Do not go out of the examination hall without the prior permission of the 
invigilator.  
4) The questions must be answered in legible handwriting.  
5) No extra supplementary answer sheets will be given for rough work on any paper. 
Rough work can be done on the last page of the main answer book.  
6) Do not refer to any book, paper, or other notes, unless it is an open -book 
examination.  
7) In an open book examination, faculty members will suggest the books/ material 
to be

referred to.  
8) Each student must bring his/her calculator and no borrowing or lending of 
calculators will be permitted during the exam. Students are not allowed to keep 
any books, paper, scientific calculators, mobile phones, smart watches, iPads, or 
any Bluetooth device  in the examination hall.  
9) Verbal or non -verbal conversation with other students is prohibited.  
10) Passing, receiving, or seeing answer papers of other students during 
examinations is strictly prohibited. Anyone w

ho willfully assists will be 
considered as guilty as one who receives it. Any type of communication or even 
looking at other students‚Äô answer books will be deemed to be an attempt at 
copying.  
11) The students must ensure that the main answer book  and that each answer 
sheet  is signed by the supervisor.  
12) All Examinations are conducted under CCTV camera and later if found that any 
one or more student(s) was copying then appropriate action will be taken.  
13) At the end of the examina

tion, the supervisor on duty would collect the answer 
books from the desk, and therefore students should stay back until their answer 
books are collected. However, those who finish the examination at least fifteen 
minutes before th e closing time could leave the hall earlier after handing in the 
answer books to the supervisor. No student will be allowed to leave the exam 
hall within the first half hour of the commencement of exams and in the last 
fifteen minutes.  
14) Under no circumstanc

es are the answer books to be taken out of the classrooms. 
Handing over the answer books to the invigilator is the responsibility of the 
students.

Page | 6 15) Penalties for the breach of examination rules and regulations may result in a 
maximum punishment of expulsion from the Programme. The punishment will be 
determined by the appropriate authority through due process.  
10. Evaluation System  
10.1 Evaluations  
AIDTM follows a continuous evaluation system that is fair and rigorous. Each course 
will have a few evaluation components which may include mid -term examination, end-
term  examination, case discussions, class participat

ion, assignments, projects, quizzes, 
class tests , and/or any other method. The concerned faculty will pre -announce the 
components and scheme of evaluation in the course outline.  
10.2 Eligibility  for Writing  End-Term  Examination  
The Institute expects students to attend all classes. A minimum of 70% attendance  is 
required by the student to be eligible to appear for the end -term examination.  
The Institute  reserves the right to allow a student with lower attendance to appear for 
th

e end -term examination.  Refer to Annexure III  for the attendance policy of the 
institute.  
Grade  A B C D F I

10.3 Grading System  
A five -point scale will be used for evaluating students in individual courses.  
For each component of evaluation, generally, marks are first awarded which are next 
converted into letter grades with the instructor deciding the range of marks for each 
letter gra

de. The component -wise letter grades are then converted into numerical 
value s (up to two decimal points) by using the Grade Conversion Table.  
The values, so obtained by a student in various components of evaluation in a course, 
would be added and the sum would be divided by 3 to obtain the final course grade 
points which will then be converted into a final letter grade for the entire course by 
using the following conversion table:  
Grade Point  3.55 to 4.33  2.55 to 3.54  1.55 to 2.54

0.55 to 1.54  0.00 to 0.54  
Grade  A B C D F

Page | 7 ‚ÄòI‚Äô grade is awarded in extraordinary situations . Refer to the subsection on the ‚ÄòI‚Äô grade.  
10.3.1 ‚ÄòI‚Äô Grade  
If a student has not fulfilled the academic requirements of a course, he/she may be 
assigned an ‚ÄúI‚Äù (Incomplete) grade temporarily, representing non -completion of the 
academic requirements of the course. First -year PGDM students must complete any 
such incomplete coursework  before they proceed for their summer internship. In the 
case of a second -year student, such

incomplete coursework  of a particular academic 
term should be completed within the following term. The ‚ÄúI‚Äù grade obtained in the sixth 
term must be completed well in time to graduate. If for any reason, the student fails to 
complete the course within the time stipulated by the course instructor and/or the 
Program  Office, then the ‚ÄúI‚Äù grade will be automatically converted into an ‚ÄúF‚Äù grade.  
If a student misses one or more components of the evaluation with prior permission, 
the following

procedure will be followed:  
I. Initially, the student will be awarded an ‚ÄúI‚Äù (incomplete) grade. ‚ÄúI‚Äù is a temporary  
grade, not intended to be shown as a final grade in a course.  
II. When the student completes the make -up requirements as specified by the 
course instructor within the specified time, ‚ÄúI‚Äù will be replaced by the final grade 
(A, B, C, D, F) awarded for that component by the instructor.  
III. In case the student fails to complete the make -up requirements as indicated  in

(Point  # II) above, the instructor will give an ‚ÄúF‚Äù for the missed component(s) of 
evaluation.  
IV. The grades given by an instructor in any component of the evaluation are final. 
The instructor will not be called upon to justify the grades if they conform to the 
norms. A student who desires clarification on the grade(s) awarded, may discuss 
the matter with the concerned instructor(s) within 4 days after receiv ing the 
grades. If any grievance regarding grading is not resolved through dis

cussion 
with the instructor or if the instructor is not available in the station, the 
concerned student may refer the ma tter to the  Dean  in writing within 2 days 
thereafter, who will then discuss the matter with the instructor, if required.  
V. In the case of the Term -III end -term examination, the students may ask queries 
through email. The faculty members are expected to respond as deemed 
necessary.

Page | 8 10.4 Grade Point Average (GPA)  
GPA for a term is the weighted average of the grade points obtained in the courses 
registered for by a student in that term, the weights being the respective course credits.  
The trimester grade point average of a student shall be calculated based on the number 
of credits (Ci) assigned to any course (i) of the trimester and the grade point (Pi) earned 
in the course.

10.5 Cumulative Grade Point Average (CGPA)  
CGP

A, as at the end of a term/year, is the weighted average of the grade points obtained 
in all the courses registered by a student up to the end including that term/year, the 
weights being the respective course credits.  Where Ci is the total no. of credits assigned 
to any trimester (ith) and Gi is the GPA obtained in that trimester (ith).

Refer to Annexure - IV for the System of Evaluation  of the Institute .  
10.6 Communication of Grades  
‚Ä¢ Course instructor

s are required to communicate to the students the marks 
obtained in the quizzes/exams as soon as possible. Instructors may 
communicate the component -wise marks directly to students, while the final 
course grade is communicated to the stude nts by the Program Office.  
‚Ä¢ The Program Office will communicate to students their final letter grades in 
various courses along with GPA and CGPA.  
10.7 Grade Dispute  
A student who  has a dispute with the grade announced in any component of the 
eval

uation or the overall grade has recourse available as per the norms and procedure 
prescribed by the Institute. Refer to Annexure V  for the grade revision appeal process.

Page | 9 11. Criteria for Award of PGDM  
A second -year student, who has satisfactorily completed the capstone  project, will 
qualify for the award of the Diploma if he/she satisfies the following criteria:  
a) He/she should have a CGPA of at least 2. 17 at the end of the second year.  
b) He/she should not have an ‚ÄúF‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äù in any course of the programme.  
c) A student should not have any outstanding dues to the institute.  
A student who  does not satisfy the criteria  mentioned above

will be asked to withdraw 
from the programme.  
A student must complete the academic requirement for the award of a diploma in a 
period not more than course duration+2 years.  
12. Academic Misconduct  
The institute attaches utmost importance to strict integrity and honesty in all segments 
of academic work. Any form of dishonesty,  including an attempt to copy or help others 
copy in any manner is strictly prohibited. Unless specified otherwise by the instructor, 
students must not collabor

ate/syndicate in any manner in the completion of home 
assignments and projects. All sources of information and ideas used for the completion 
of the assignments and projects must be explicitly acknowledged. In other words, the 
non-referenced part of the answer as presented to the instructor should be the 
independent work of the student/s.  
12.1 Unfair Means in Exams  
AIDTM has a zero -tolerance policy towards academic and non -academic misconduct. 
One of the academic misconducts is cheatin

g in the examination. The procedure for 
handling cheating cases is described below:  
If a student is found cheating or attempting to cheat, the invigilator must  take on -the-
spot action as follows:  
I. If the attempt is minor  the concerned invigilator can take spot action like giving a 
warning, changing the seat, marking the answer paper with a deduction of some 
points (if a concerned faculty member is the invigilator) or anything else that is 
considered appropriate in that situation.

II. If the attempt is not minor , then,  
o The invigilator who has malpractice should take the concerned student 
out of the exam hall, take him to another room and take the student‚Äôs 
statement in writing.

Page | 10 o Collect the answer paper written so far by the student and keep it 
together with the statement of the student.  
o Send the student back to the exam hall, give another answer paper and 
ask the student to continue from where  left off. 
o The student will not be entitled to any extra time to compensate for the 
loss of time during this exercise.  
o On completion of the examination, the concerned invigilator should give 
his statement about how the student was caught. This invig

ilator‚Äôs 
statement along with the student‚Äôs statement and both answer papers 
must be submitted to the Program  Office  for further action.  
III. The Programme Chair will then refer the matter to the Disciplinary Committee for 
appropriate action. From this point ‚ÄúConsequences of Misconduct‚Äô rules and 
procedures  will be applicable with a window for redressal by the aggrieved party.  
12.2 Plagiarism  
Plagiarism is professionally unethical. AIDTM expects students to demonstrate a high 
level

of understanding about plagiarism and avoid being party to plagiarism. (Refer to 
Annexure VI  for guidelines to avoid plagiarism)  
‚Ä¢ Stealing the words  and ideas of someone else, without any acknowledgement  
is an  example of plagiarism. In any take -home assignment and project as well 
as in any open book examination one must not plagiarise.  
‚Ä¢ The concerned faculty may impose severe penalties  if any student has indulged 
in plagiarism activity.  
‚Ä¢ If the plagiarism case is referred to

the Institute Disciplinary Committee for 
appropriate action, then the action may vary from zero in the component to 
expulsion from the programme. The decision of the Institute Disciplinary 
Committee will be final and binding to all.  
‚Ä¢ However, a student may file a mercy petition to the Dean , who will decide on a 
case -to-case  basis whether to grant mercy or not.  
12.3 Mobile Phone  
‚Ä¢ The use  of mobile phones  in and around classrooms is strictly prohibited. Use of 
a camera in a mobil

e anywhere on campus for any undesired purpose is strictly 
prohibited.  
‚Ä¢ Keep the mobile phone switched off / silent during the class.  
‚Ä¢ Anyone who violates  these rules may be charged a spot fine of Rs. 500.

Page | 11 ‚Ä¢ Refer to Annexure VII  for the Mobile Phone Policy of the Institute and abide by 
the same.  
12.4 Other Norms of Conduct  
‚Ä¢ Canvassing for grades is strictly prohibited.  
‚Ä¢ Marking proxy attendance for others or having attendance marked by others will 
attract severe punishments.  
‚Ä¢ Cases of indiscipline or misconduct such as mass abstention from classes, 
irresponsible behaviour inside or outside the classes, use of unethical practices 
during the summer internship/placement

or violation of the rules and 
regulations of the programme will be severely dealt with.  
‚Ä¢ The case method of instruction depends upon the confidence of businesses 
from which data are collected. Case names and data are frequently disguised. 
Students should ensure that the confidentiality of the data obtained for 
educational purposes is not viola ted in any way.  
‚Ä¢ It is expected that for the group assignments group members contribute equally 
to complete the assignment. All the members o

f the group should actively 
participate in the group assignment. Appropriate actions will be taken if the 
faculty observes that all the group members are not participating equally in the 
group projects.  
‚Ä¢ It is expected that the students will come  prepared for the class with a reading 
of prescribed material, preparation of cases, etc.  
13. Non-Academic Misconduct  
The Institute attaches utmost importance to professional behaviour from all students 
in and outside the class. Misconduct o

f a non -academic nature is also taken very 
seriously in our Institute. Serious  misconduct may lead to expulsion from the Institute.  
13.1 Ragging on Campus  
Ragging of fresh students by the senior batch, in any form, is a criminal offence and is 
strictly prohibited. Get familiarized with the Anti Ragging Rules and Policies (Refer to 
Annexure VIII ) of the Institute and comply with them.  
13.2 Misbehavior  
‚Ä¢ Students are expected to behave respectfully to all on our campus and outside.
Any disrespectful behaviour may invite disciplinary action, as per the Institute

Page | 12 policy, ranging from a fine to expulsion from the programme.  
‚Ä¢ Smoking is prohibited on the campus.  
‚Ä¢ Students are not permitted to run any commercial venture on or outside the 
campus. They are also not permitted to associate/help/advise any organizations 
on a commercial basis and to receive any honorarium for the services rendered 
during their studies at the Institute.  
‚Ä¢ Students are not permitted to deal with the Institute employees,  including 
contract workers directly

. Any complaints regarding the work /behaviour  of such 
employees should be reported to the concerned administrative head.  
‚Ä¢ Students are required to attend the lectures organized by the Institute, as a part 
of the academic non -credit but compulsory activity of the programme.  
14. Consequences of Misconduct  
Academic and non -academic misconduct would invite severe penalties . 
I. Any academic or non-academic misconduct may invite severe penalties  ranging 
from a simple warning to expuls

ion from the programme , depending upon the 
severity of misconduct(s) assessed by the concerned authority.  
II. The penalty for a breach of academic discipline would be first decided by the 
concerned faculty as per the rules of the institute.  
III. However, a faculty may refer the case of academic misconduct to the Programme 
Chair, who in turn will ask the Institute's Academic /  Disciplinary Committee to 
decide . 
IV. The cases of non -academic misconduct can be referred to the Programme

Chair, 
who will attempt to address the situation and decide on a penalty, if any. However, 
if the nature of misconduct is such it may warrant severe penalty, the Programme 
Chair will refer the matter to the Institute  Disciplinary  Committee, which will make  
a final decision.  
V. The decision of the Institute Disciplinary Committee will be conveyed by the 
Programme Chair to the concerned student. The decision of the Institute 
Disciplinary Committee is binding to all.  
VI. A student has

a right to make a mercy appeal to the Dean . In consultation with the 
concerned instructor and the Institute Academic Committee, the Dean  will make a 
final decision to either accept or reject the mercy appeal or change the penalty. 
The decision of the Dean  shall be final. A student expelled from the programme on 
the grounds of academic or non -academic misconduct is ineligible for seeking

Page | 13 admission to the Institute.  
15. Infrastructure and Facilities  
15.1 Library and Reading Room   
I. The AIDTM Library is emerging as a premier academic and research institution 
known for its user -centric approach, innovation, and excellence. It supports faculty, 
students, and staff in discovering, evaluating, managing, and utilizing scholarly 
resources i n both print and digital formats. The library offers conducive 
environments for study and research, complemented by superi

or facilities and 
services.  
II. The Library & Reading Room is centrally located and boasts an extensive collection 
of resources, including books, journals, magazines, newspapers, student reports, 
audiovisual materials, and online resources. These cover a wide array of subjects 
such as Ec onomics, Banking and Finance, Business Management, Marketing, 
Python, R Programming, Machine Learning, MIS, Big Data, Data Analytics, 
Technology Management , Artificial Intelligence and Data Science.  
I

II. The library operates seamlessly with an advanced digital system managed through 
the Integrated Library Management System, KOHA. Additionally, all users benefit 
from Zotero, an open -access reference management software.  
IV. Library membership is available at no cost to regular and visiting faculty, students, 
staff, and other stakeholders of the Institute upon enrollment. It holds 
organizational memberships with other academic institutions to supplement its 
resources and broad en acces

s for students and faculty. Please refer to Annexure 
IX: Library Code of Conduct for detailed information on the library's rules and 
regulations.

15.2 Computer Centre  
The computer  laboratory is equipped with high -end Intel i5 desktop DELL computers 
and network devices with Wi -Fi internet connectivity. Our Networks

are connected via 
Fiber Optic cables, Routers, Switches, LANs  as well as Wi -Fi hotspots to provide wireless 
connectivity for all the stakeholders.

Page | 14 All classrooms and other academic areas are equipped with digital smart art audio and 
visual teaching aids, best -in-class  equipment, and high -definition  closed -circuit  
cameras. (Refer to Annexure X  for computer centre rules  and regulations)  
15.3 Recreation Facility  
AIDTM believes in student -driven institutions  when it is a matter of student activities. 
Students take initiative  and we provide support if the proposed activity is expected to 
add value. (Refer to Ann

exure XI  for recreation facility and Annexure XVII  for general 
rules and regulations)  
15.4 Classroom and Tutorial Rooms  
AIDTM intends to provide the best teaching and learning environment for the students. 
Our philosophy is that a conducive learning environment prevails for students to 
actively participate  in the learning process.  (Refer to Annexure XII  for details)  
15.5 Stationery  
Please note that printing facilities and any kind of stationery will not be provided by the 
instit

ute. Students are required to manage their stationery needs independently.  
16. Student  Support System  
AIDTM provides various platforms to express grievances by students and handling that 
for suitable solution works well because students can approach any faculty or a 
Program Chair or Dean with their issues and problems. Still, we have provided for a 
formal Student Grievance Redressal system.  
I. A student who has any grievance can call or write to the Chairperson of the 
Student Grievanc

e Committee.  
II. The Chairperson of the Committee will investigate the matter as appropriate and 
put up the case with the Student Grievance Committee within fifteen days for 
suitable action.  
III. The Chairperson of the Committee will communicate the decision to the 
concerned student within seven days of the Committee‚Äôs decision.  
IV. If the concerned student is not satisfied with the redressal action, he/she can 
write to the Dean within one week of the date of communication of action to

him/her.  
V. The Dean will investigate the matter and take an appropriate decision after 
hearing from all concerned parties and investigating the matter. The Dean will 
communicate the final decision to the students and concerned parties within

Page | 15 fifteen days of the appeal.  
16.1 Academic Committee  
All the decisions related to academic issues are taken by the Academic Committee in 
the institute.  
The objectives of the Academic Committee are as follows:  
‚Ä¢ To decide on the eligibility of a student for re -assessment of his/her failure in a 
particular subject or number of subjects.  
‚Ä¢ To conduct one -on-one interactions with students who apply for re -assessment 
of their failure in a particular subject or number of s

ubjects.  
‚Ä¢ To improve student attendance and ensure regularity in attendance. (Refer to

ny general discipline

16.4 Student

s Grievance Redressal System  
AIDTM provides various platforms to express grievances by students and handling that 
for suitable solution works well because students can approach any faculty or a 
Program Office  or Dean with their issues and problems. Still, we have provided for a 
formal Student Grievance Redressal system.  
‚Ä¢ A student who has any grievance can call or write to the Chairperson of the 
Student Grievance Committee.

Page | 16 ‚Ä¢ The Chairperson of the Committee will investigate the matter as appropriate and 
put up the case with the Student Grievance Committee within fifteen days for 
suitable action.  
‚Ä¢ The Chairperson of the Committee will communicate the decision to the 
concerned student within seven days of the Committee‚Äôs decision.  
‚Ä¢ If the concerned student is not satisfied with the redressal action, he/she can 
write to the Dean within one week of the date of communication of action to 
him/he

r.  
‚Ä¢ The Dean will investigate the matter and take an appropriate decision after 
hearing from all concerned parties and investigating the matter. The Dean  will 
communicate the final decision to the students and concerned parties within 
fifteen days of the appeal.

Redressal Committee (WGRC)

regulations (Clause 3 of the AICTE regulations, 2012), a Grievance

need arises.

RC) / (Women

Page | 20 Annexure I II: Attendance Policy  
PGDM is a fully residential programme , and students are required to have 100% 
attendance. However, for any genuine reason, students can be permitted to remain 
absent, with prior permission, for a maximum of up to 30% of total sessions.  
‚Ä¢ If a student fails to secure a minimum of 70% attendance, including absence due 
to medical reasons, s/he will not be eligible to appear for the End Term 
Examination.  
‚Ä¢ There will not be any provision for

a makeup quiz/examination/p resentation etc., 
missed by the student.  
‚Ä¢ Attendance is different (independent component) and hence grades for Class 
Participation (CP) will not be awarded merely for attendance.  
‚Ä¢ The Class Representative (CR) will be responsible for coordinating  with the 
respective faculty on any matter about  seating  and attendance requirements.  
Note:  For late coming into the classroom NO attendance will be given.

Page | 22 Annexure V: Grade Revision Appeal Process   
A student has the right to appeal regarding the component and final grade in any 
subject. The process will be as follows:  
‚Ä¢ The student will initially attempt to resolve the grade dispute with the concerned 
faculty member. The student will make his or her appeal in writing to the faculty 
member, stating the reasons why he or she feels the grade is incorrect. Such an 
appeal must  be made to the faculty member within a week from the

date of 
announcement of the grade.  
‚Ä¢ The faculty member will review the appeal and decide. The decision must be 
communicated in writing within a week of the date of appeal.  
‚Ä¢ If the student is not satisfied with the decision of the faculty member, he/she 
can appeal the faculty member‚Äôs decision by writing to the Programme Chair 
within a week from the date of communication of the decision by the faculty 
members. The appeal must include reasons, supportive evidence, a copy of the 
written

appeal to the faculty member, a copy of the faculty member‚Äôs reply , and 
all other appropriate documents.  
‚Ä¢ The Programme Chair will call the Academic Committee meeting for the review 
and decision on the appeal. Such a meeting will be held within fifteen days of 
receiving such an appeal. The Programme Chair will communicate the decision 
to the Academic Committee  within two days of the decision.  
A student can appeal against  the decision of the Academic Committee to the Dean . The 
deci
sion of the Dean  is final and binding to all concerned parties.

Page | 23 Annexure V I: Guidelines to Avoid Plagiarism  
The purpose of these guidelines is to appraise the students to make them aware of 
academic integrity, plagiarism & its consequences and referencing style in assignments, 
project reports or independent study submissions. For detailed understanding, students  
are encouraged to refer to the suggested referencing style given in this note.  
Note that at AIDTM, we expect our students to demonstrate utmost academic integrity 
and understa

nd the consequences if we do not.  
What is Academic Integrity?  
Academic Integrity is an honest and responsible scholarship. As a student, you are 
expected to submit original work and give credit to other people's ideas. Maintaining 
your academic integrity involves:  
‚Ä¢ Creating and expressing your ideas in coursework.  
‚Ä¢ Acknowledging all sources of information.  
‚Ä¢ Completing assignments independently or acknowledging collaboration.  
‚Ä¢ Accurately reporting results when conducting your re

search, experiment, or 
concerning  labs.  
‚Ä¢ Honesty during examinations.  
Academic integrity is the foundation of institutional success. Learning how to express 
original ideas, cite sources, work independently, and report results accurately and 
honestly are skills that carry students beyond their academic careers . Academic 
dishonesty not only cheats the student of valuable learning experiences, but can result 
in a failing grade on assignments, a failing grade in a course, or even expulsi

on from the 
institute.  
Plagiarism  
Plagiarism (from the Latin plagiarius, an abductor, and plagiare, to steal) is defined as 
‚Äú‚Ä¶ the appropriation of another person‚Äôs ideas, processes, results or words without 
giving appropriate credit.‚Äù  
At AIDTM, we recognize that the open exchange of ideas plays a vital role in academic  
endeavour, as often it is only through discussion with others that one is fully able to 
process information or to crystallize an elusive concept. Therefore, students

generally 
are encouraged to engage in conversations with their teachers and classmates ab out 
their courses, their interests, and even their assignments. These kinds of discussions 
and debates in some ways represent the essence of life in an academic community like

Page | 24 ours. And yet, all students need to acknowledge  clearly when they have relied upon or 
incorporated the work of others. To ensure the proper use of sources while at the same 
time recognizing and preserving the importance of the academic dialogue, we have 
adopted the following policy:  
‚ÄúIt is expected that all homework assignments, projects, reports, papers, theses, and 
examinations and any other work submitted for academic credit will be the student‚Äôs 
own. Students should alw

ays take great care to distinguish their ideas and knowledge 
from information derived from sources. The term ‚Äúsources‚Äù includes not only primary 
and secondary material published in print or online, but also information and opinions 
gained directly from other people. No student shall claim or submit the academic work 
of another as one‚Äôs own. Students who, for whatever reason, submit work either not 
their own or  without clear attribution to its sources will be subject to disciplinary action,

up to and  including a requirement to withdraw from the Institute.‚Äù  
Plagiarism may be accidental or blatant and there is even self -plagiarism. However, 
students are held to the same standards whether  they knew they were plagiarizing or 
whether  they were plagiarizing themselves or someone else.  
Accidental or Unintentional  
One may not even know that they are plagiarizing. It is the student's responsibility to 
make certain that they understand the difference between quoting and paraph

rasing, 
as well as the proper way to cite material.  
Blatant  
Here, students understand they are plagiarizing. Purposefully using someone else's 
ideas or work without proper acknowledgement  is plagiarism. This includes turning in 
borrowed or bought research papers as one's own.  
Self 
Turning in the same term paper (or substantially the same paper) for two courses 
without getting permission from one's instructor is plagiarism.  
Unless authorized by their instructors, students are expect

ed to do their own, original 
work on each assignment in each class. A student who recycles his or her coursework  
from one class to another may face an allegation of academic dishonesty.  
An instructor who believes a student has committed an act of plagiarism should take 
appropriate action,  which includes the issuing of a ‚Äúpenalty grade‚Äù, defined as ‚Äúa grade

Page | 25 assigned to a student by a faculty member based on a charge of academic misconduct‚Äù. 
A penalty grade can include but is not limited to, a failing grade on the assignment or 
in the course.  
What constitutes plagiarism or cheating?  
This might occur in an assignment when:  
‚Ä¢ copying word -for-word directly from a text  
‚Ä¢ paraphrasing the words from a text very closely  
‚Ä¢ using text downloaded from the internet  
‚Ä¢ borrowing statistics or assembled facts from another person or

source without 
acknowledging  
‚Ä¢ copying or downloading figures, photographs, pictures or diagrams without 
acknowledging sources  
‚Ä¢ copying from the notes or essays of a fellow student  
‚Ä¢ copying from your notes, a text, tutorial, video or lecture, that contains direct 
quotations.  
Referencing styles  
A referencing style is a set of rules telling you how to acknowledge the thoughts, ideas 
and works of others in a particular way. Referencing is a crucial part of successful 
academic  writ

ing and is key to your assignments and research. At AIDTM, it is 
encouraged that the students follow the APA referencing style, details of which are as 
follows:  
APA (American Psychological Association)  
The American Psychological Association publishes a style guide, the Publication 
Manual of the American Psychological Association, which is commonly used by writers, 
editors and students in social science subjects. The APA also provides a free basic 
online tutorial for using the APA Style

which includes guidance on how to reference.  
APA Links  
The following, freely available APA web guides may also help you to reference your work 
using the APA style:  
Cardiff University Information Literacy Resource Bank - APA Referencing Tutorial 
University of Wisconsin - Madison - Writing Centre APA Documentation

Page | 26 Purdue University Online Writing Lab (OWL) - APA Formatting and Style Guide  
Plagiarism Check  
There are some paid as well as free plagiarism check software available. The students 
are advised to use one of them before turning in  any assignment or project. The free 
online plagiarism check can be done at any of the following websites (there are more):  
https://www.thepensters.com/free -plagiarism -checker -for-students -online.html 
http://plagiarisma.net/  
http://www.plagsca
n.com/seesources/

Page | 27 Annexure V II: Mobile Phone Policy  
Mobile phones  are a useful gadget and their  use in the right places cannot be denied. 
However, to facilitate  healthy academic processes, we adopt the following policy 
regulations regarding the use of mobile phones on campus:  
During the class , all students must keep their phones in switch -off or silent mode.  
If a mobile phone rings during the class, or if a student is found using a mobile phone 
in the class, the phone may be confiscat

ed immediately by the faculty member, who will 
deposit the phone in the Program Office.  
In the examination hall, all the students must switch off  their mobile phones and keep 
them on the main table of the examination hall. Keeping a switched -off mobile in the 
pocket is also not permissible during the examination.  If the mobile is found with any 
student during the examination, it will be confiscated and deposited in the program  
office.  
The confiscated mobile can be returned to the co

ncerned student only after  a fine of 
Rs. 2000/ - (1st Time), and Rs. 5000/ - (2nd Time) is paid by the student. Thereafter, if 
a student is found with a mobile phone, it will be finally confiscated. This is without 
prejudice to the Institute‚Äôs right to take suitable action against the student for breach 
of academic discipline.  
The Institute has the right  to look up the data on the mobile, especially when the mobile 
phone is confiscated during examination, and if any objectionable materi

al is found 
then appropriate steps will be initiated for academic malpractice.  
The mobile of a student who  has violated this policy a third time  will be confiscated,  
and further appropriate actions will be taken by the disciplinary committee of the 
Institute.

Page | 28 Annexure VI II: Anti -Ragging Rules and Regulations  
The higher education community is aware that ragging in higher education institutions 
is a great concern for all authorities including law enforcement agencies. Prevention 
and prohibition of ragging on campus are very important. In this context, the Report  
submitted by the Raghavan Committee constituted by the Hon‚Äôble Supreme Court in 
SLP No.24295/2006 is relevant. Hon‚Äôble Supreme Court of India accepted the various 
recomm

endations made by the Raghavan Committee and made it mandatory for the 
concerned to im plement the following recommendations.  
The punishment to be meted out must be exemplary and justifiably harsh to act as a 
deterrent against the recurrence of such incidents.  
For every single incident of ragging where the victim or his parent/guardian or the Head 
of Institution is not satisfied with the institutional arrangement for action, a First 
Information Report must be filed without exception by t

he institutional authorit ies with 
the local police authorities. Any failure on the part of the institutional authority or 
negligence or deliberate delay in lodging the FIR with the local police shall be construed 
to be an act of culpable negligence on the part of the authorities b y the Courts. All 
efforts should be made to ensure that cases involving ragging are taken up on a priority 
basis to send the correct message that ragging is not only to be discouraged but also 
to be dealt with s

ternly.  
Hence, it is emphasized that ragging of and among students of this Institution in any 
form at any place will not be tolerated and it is banned. For this purpose, the following 
activities and/or actions shall be construed as forms of ragging.  
The Institution has an Anti -Ragging Committee headed by a senior faculty of the 
Institute. If the committee finds that there is a prima facie case of ragging on the 
complaint received, the committee will take immediate action including the f

iling of an 
FIR with the local police depending on the seriousness of the case.  
Depending upon the nature and gravity of the offense  as established by the Anti 
Ragging Committee of the Institute, the possible punishments for those found guilty of 
ragging at the Institute level shall be any one or any combination of the following:  
‚Ä¢ Cancellation of admission  
‚Ä¢ Suspension from attending classes  
‚Ä¢ Withholding/withdrawing scholarship/fellowship and other benefits  
‚Ä¢ Debarring from appea

ring in any test/examination or other evaluation process  
‚Ä¢ Withholding results

Page | 29 ‚Ä¢ Debarring from representing the institution in any regional, national , or 
international meet, tournament, youth festival, etc.  
‚Ä¢ Suspension/expulsion from the hostel  
‚Ä¢ Rustication from the institution for a period as may be determined by an 
appropriate authority  
‚Ä¢ Expulsion from the institution and consequent debarring from admission to any 
other institution of AIDTM.  
‚Ä¢ Fine of Rupees 25,000/ - 
Collective punishment: when the persons committing or abetting the crime

of ragging 
are not identified, the institution shall resort to collective punishment as a deterrent to 
ensure community pressure on the potential triggers.  
As a preventive measure, all the existing students, freshers , and their parents/guardians 
shall submit an undertaking in the prescribed form at the beginning of the academic 
session itself failing which the concerned student will not be allowed to attend classes 
until he/she and his/her parents/guardians submit the said undertaking.

All the students at the Institute are advised to abide by the instructions scrupulously 
to ensure a healthy academic atmosphere and make it a ragging -free campus.  
 
Strict observance of the instructions and cooperation with the Institute in its efforts 
to ensure a ‚ÄúRagging Free AIDTM‚Äù is highly solicited.

Duties and Responsibilities of WGRC:  
‚Ä¢ To examine and grievance letter received from the women staff/

students regarding 
the sexual harassment.  
‚Ä¢ To examine and investigate each complaint received from the women

Page | 36 staff/students by collecting the required evidence/data from related people.  
‚Ä¢ To recommend  to the concerned authority for further action.  
‚Ä¢ To counsel the women staff/students concerned/ about  a possible solution for their 
grievances.  
‚Ä¢ The committee should suggest a suitable solution to a problem faced by the women 
staff/students regarding matters relating to sexual harassment to the concerned 
authorities.  
Duties and Responsibilities SGRC:  
‚Ä¢ To take corrective & ef

fective actions to address students'  and parents'  Grievances.  
‚Ä¢ To form and provide a mechanism to supervise activities of Students'  grievances  
‚Ä¢ To provide the right direction and counsel whenever required and guide them in 
improvement.

Page | 37 Annexure X VII: General Rules and Regulations  
Dress Code  
While there is no formal uniform recommended by the institute, students are advised 
to wear semi -formal clothing and clothing that is acceptable in an academic 
atmosphere. For important days, a formal dress code will be compulsory. Students 
should closely follow the dress code guidelines laid down on such days. The corporate 
relationship cell has designed a common placement dress code which includes formal 
clothes w

ith a blazer. The blazer must be worn during the placement process.  
General Rules  
‚Ä¢ All students must carry  their ID card on the campus.  
‚Ä¢ There is a book bank facility available in the library  for the students.  
‚Ä¢ Keep the campus clean.  
‚Ä¢ Absence from classes will attract disciplinary actions including monetary penalty.  
‚Ä¢ Proxy, unfair practices in the examination, unacknowledged material quoted in 
assignments , project reports , etc. will invite appropriate disciplinary action.

‚Ä¢ Students are not permitted to use the institute's telephone for any purpose.  
‚Ä¢ Do not use mobile phones in the classroom and the foyer. Mobile phones ringing in 
the classroom shall be confiscated and penalties  will be charged.  
‚Ä¢ Chewing  tobacco or smoking is strictly prohibited on the campus.  
Classroom Norms  
‚Ä¢ Students are expected to follow the rules and norms laid down by individual faculty 
members in their respective sessions.  
‚Ä¢ Students are expected to foster an environment

that is conducive to learning.  
‚Ä¢ Students are encouraged to allow fair and free exchange of ideas and thoughts in 
the classroom.  
‚Ä¢ Students are expected to maintain discipline and decorum in the class.  
‚Ä¢ Students are expected to maintain an atmosphere of mutual trust and respect in 
the class and on campus.  
Preparation for Classes  
‚Ä¢ Students are expected to have read the relevant study material for the topics to be 
discussed before attending each session. This practice helps to impro
ve  the

Page | 38 understanding and performance of students.  
‚Ä¢ Students should carry the required study material for the class.

Page | 39 Annexure XVI II: Medical Facility  
In case of a medical emergency, please contact AIDTM Reception Extn. 201 or the 
Program Office on Mobile: 9099981586. To the extent possible, preference should be 
given to the Emergency Ambulance Service ( Toll-Free  Number 108) as it comes with a 
well-trained Emergency Medical Technician to render quality pre -hospital care.
